text: BACKGROUND : Fibrin deposition and thrombosis have been implicated in both allograft rejection and vasculopathy after cardiac transplantation .

Because monocytes play a pivotal role in the pathophysiology of intravascular coagulation activation through their ability to synthesize <extra_id_0> tissue factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , we asked ( 1 ) whether monocyte <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation occurs in cardiac transplant recipients and ( 2 ) whether monocyte <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is affected by treatment with cyclosporin A ( CsA ) .

text: METHODS AND RESULTS : We measured levels of <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and highly purified monocytes / macrophages from 10 consecutive cardiac transplant recipients and 10 healthy control subjects .

<extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity generated by both unstimulated and endotoxin - stimulated cells was significantly higher in transplant recipients than in control subjects ( P < .05 ) .

Increased monocyte <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in transplant recipients was shown to be adversely affected by treatment with CsA : <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> induction was markedly reduced by CsA serum concentrations reaching peak CsA drug levels .

text: CONCLUSIONS : This study demonstrates that <extra_id_0> TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activation , occurring in mononuclear cells of cardiac transplant recipients , is inhibited by treatment with CsA .
